title.narrative: Emergency Obstetric Care and essential Maternal Health Services in the Ebola Context

description.narrative:
Sierra Leone has one of the highest maternal mortality rates in the world with a ratio of 1,165 deaths per 100,000 live births as indicated in the recent 2013 DHS. According to the UN Population Estimates for 2015, there will be 123 000 pregnant women and girls, as well as 500 000 women in need of contraception in Sierra Leone.

To accelerate the reduction of maternal and newborn deaths, it is crucial that the GoSL and its partners be in a position to provide at least four Antenatal Care visits, safe delivery attended by a skilled health worker, Postnatal Care (PNC), family planning counseling and services, emergency obstetric and newborn care and counseling, testing and referral for HIV/STIs.

The EVD outbreak threatens to reverse the recent gains made by the Government and its partners. The combination of overwhelmed and collapsing health systems, widespread panic, and quarantine has left pregnant women and women seeking family planning with few options. Pregnant women are faced with the fear of both dying from Ebola and dying during childbirth. Many women are delivering at home, in most cases attended by TBAs. Attendance in health facilities and provision of basic reproductive health services have dropped drastically. According to 2014 UNFPA estimates, more than 40 000 women could die of complications of pregnancy and childbirth, if the required life-saving emergency obstetric care is not urgently provided.

The purpose of this programme is to provide Emergency Obstetric Care to women and adolescent girls as well as essential Maternal Health services including ANC, Safe Deliveries, PNC, Family Planning and HIV/STIs. This will contribute to guaranteeing that health needs of women, girls and newborns are met and also contribute to reducing maternal mortality, neonatal mortality, unwanted pregnancies and preventing the exacerbation of HIV epidemic because of the Ebola outbreak.
